DOC.HEAD: Noriega Takes Asylum at Vatican Embassy
Eds: New thruout to ADD Vatican comment, seizure of town, new casualty count. No pickup.
LaserPhotos NY9,10,11
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops and armored vehicles ringed the Vatican Embassy early today after deposed strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega took refuge there and asked for political asylum. American troops captured the town of Santiago southwest of Panama City, but otherwise fighting died down as Christmas came to Panama. About 40 soldiers kept watch in the pre-dawn darkness as a helicopter, its running lights turned off, landed several times across the street from the Vatican Embassy, then took off. The chopper was not seen picking up or dropping off anyone. The Vatican, in its first official statement on the situation, said today that Noriega took refuge in the embassy Sunday after expressing ``the will to end the conflict'' between his supporters and the United States. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said it was too early to say if Noriega would be handed over to the United States, where he faces drug charges, or given passage to another country. Under international law, embassies are sacrosanct ground and U.S. troops cannot legally enter the papal embassy to arrest Noriega. Earlier, an official at the Vatican said he doubted the embassy would immediately turn Noriega over to the United States. Panamanians banged pots and pans and cheered when word of Noriega's surrender spread through the capital, littered with glass and looted bare after five days of fighting. The American invasion, which began at midnight Tuesday, has killed at least 23 American soldiers and two American civilians, and nearly 300 Panamanians, according to U.S. figures announced today. Many Panamanian victims are believed to be civilians. Lt. Col. Jerry Murguia told reporters at a Southern Command briefing today that American troops had captured Santiago, 120 miles southwest of Panama City, taking 188 prisoners and seizing several hundred small arms. ``It was a quiet night. That's the good news,'' he said. There was little else to celebrate in this mainly Roman Catholic country. ``What am I going to tell my 6-year-old daughter? I cannot tell her Santa Claus was killed by a bomb,'' said one woman in a middle-class neighborhood Christmas Eve. Residents roamed their neighborhoods, cleaned glass and trash off streets and put up Christmas lights. Noriega drove himself or was driven to the embassy in a car at about 3 p.m. Sunday, an informed military source said. None of the 26,000 American troops searching for Noriega in this Central American country was at the embassy at the time. American soldiers had surrounded the Nicaraguan and Cuban embassies after rumors Noriega might seek refuge there. Navarro rejected the idea the Vatican was ``embarrassed'' by Noriega's decision to seek refuge at its embassy and depicted it as an opportunity to bring peace to the country. ``I can announce with satisfaction that the conflict in Panama seems to be nearing a solution without further shedding of blood,'' he said in a four-paragraph statement. ``And this is good news for Christmas Day.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States would continue to seek ways to bring Noriega to the United States. Asked if anyone would get the $1 million reward the Bush administration offered for Noriega's capture, Fitzwater said, ``No, I don't think so.'' Gen. Maxwell Thurman, chief of the U.S. Southern Command, said he ordered the Vatican Embassy surrounded after Noriega's surrender to prevent Noriega supporters from ``blowing into the place. I would not want them to come with an armored car and blow their way into the embassy.'' Noriega surfaced a few hours after three high-ranking members of his Defense Forces surrendered and another pledged loyalty to the U.S.-backed government. Witnesses said they saw several Noriega officials, including former acting president Manuel Solis Palma, entering the embassy. The Italian news agency ANSA reported from Panama City that 32 people had sought asylum from the Vatican, including high officials of the Panamanian Defense Forces and political parties of the Noriega regime. Panamanians cheered as word spread that Noriega had turned himself in. Hundreds congregated at the embassy. ``The man has fallen! He is gone!'' some shouted. A radio station went on the air with a nationalistic song called ``Patria'' (Fatherland), written and sung by Panamanian Ruben Blades. ``Now we can have Christmas!' said one man in Panama City as he grabbed a friend and hugged him. ``I don't have a turkey in the house, we don't even have any hamburger. All we have is a can of sardines, but what the hell!'' Food and medical supplies were in short supply, and stores were ransacked by looters. Combat from Noriega loyalists dwindled Sunday, but there was fighting in the working-class San Miguelito district, one of those where the pro-Noriega paramilitary Dignity Battalions are strongest. Thurman estimated the battalions number about 1,800. They have been joined by an unknown number of Noriega's original 15,000-member Defense Forces. Murguia said today that 23 U.S. soldiers had been killed and 285 wounded since the invasion began. The Pentagon on Sunday said 25 U.S. soldiers were killed. It then changed that figure to 24, saying one death had been counted twice. Murguia, in announcing his figures, said two deaths were counted twice. The latest figures no longer listed a soldier as missing. Pentagon officials also said two American civilians had been killed. Murguia said 290 ``enemy'' troops had been killed, 121 wounded and 3,780 captured. It was not clear whether the figures included both Defense Forces and Dignity Brigade personnel. Dr. Elmer Miranda, director of Santo Tomas Hospital, put the Panamanian death toll at 260 and said many victims were civilians.
